metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of A’rou Superstation, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of A’rou Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (100.464° E, 38.047° N) was located on a cold grassland surface in the Caodaban village, A’rou Town, Qilian County, Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3033 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45C; 1, 2, 5, 10, 15 and 25 m, towards north), wind speed profile (010C; 1, 2, 5, 10, 15 and 25 m, towards north), wind direction profile (020C; 2 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 5 m, towards south), four-component radiometer (CNR4; 5 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 5 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR-LITE; 5 m, towards south, vertically upward), soil heat flux (HFP01SC; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m, 2 m in the south of tower), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (TCAV; -0.02, -0.04 m, 2 m in the south of tower), soil temperature profile (109; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.06, -0.1, -0.15, -0.2, -0.3, -0.4, -0.6, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6, -2, -2.4, -2.8 and -3.2 m, 3 duplicates in -0.04 m and -0.1 m), and soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04, -0.06, -0.1, -0.15, -0.2, -0.3, -0.4, -0.6, -0.8, -1.2, -1.6, -2, -2.4, -2.8 and -3.2 m, 3 duplicates in -0.04 m and -0.1 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_1 m, Ta_2 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m and Ta_25 m; RH_1 m, RH_2 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m and RH_25 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_1 m, Ws_2 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m and Ws_25 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_2 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/(s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm_1, Ts_4 cm_2, Ts_4 cm_3, Ts_6 cm, Ts_10 cm_1, Ts_10 cm_2, Ts_10 cm_3, Ts_15 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_30 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, Ts_160 cm, Ts_200 cm, Ts_240 cm, Ts_280 cm and Ts_320 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm_1, Ms_4 cm_2, Ms_4 cm_3, Ms_6 cm, Ms_10 cm_1, Ms_10 cm_2, Ms_10 cm_3, Ms_15 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_30 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, Ms_160 cm, Ms_200 cm, Ms_240 cm, Ms_280 cm and Ms_320 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2020-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.
research objective: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China.
This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.
challenges: However, several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, which hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

However, the above modeling efforts suffered from 1) the availability of the forcing data (only two weather stations operated by the Chinese Meteorological Administration functioned in the upper reaches of the HRB) and 2) a lack of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.
Unfortunately, this did not work well due to the influence of strong wind. Therefore, snow density data, which can be calculated using snow depth and SWE data, are not available at present.
methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

Concept Completion.Question: When does the data collection process in an alpine hydrology observation network face challenges, and what are the primary obstacles encountered?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor snow cover and its properties in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: Snow cover properties are collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. For instance, snow depth is measured by SR50A, an ultrasonic sensor that determines distance by sending out pulses and listening for echoes. Snow water equivalent (SWE) is measured by a GMON device, and blowing snow flux is monitored using FlowCapt at various heights.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that captures freeze-thaw processes in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: High-resolution soil physics datasets were obtained from a frozen ground observation superstation to capture freeze-thaw processes. These datasets include soil temperature and moisture profiles measured at multiple layers, extending to a depth of 3.2 meters, to analyze soil hydrothermal features during freeze-thaw cycles.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting meteorological data in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge in collecting meteorological data in alpine regions is the cold and harsh climate, along with high altitude and complex topography, which can inhibit consistent data collection. For example, the scarcity of observation data due to these conditions has hindered the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the meteorological observation systems used in alpine regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: automatic meteorological stations, sensors at various heights and directions, air temperature and humidity sensors, wind speed and direction sensors, instruments for measuring atmospheric pressure and precipitation, four-component radiation, surface radiation temperature

Feature Specification.Question: What challenges are associated with collecting hydrological data in alpine environments?
Feature Specification.Answer: harsh weather conditions, high altitudes, complex topography, data gaps, inaccuracies, technological barriers, scarcity of observation data

Feature Specification.Answer: long-term hydrometeorological data, snow cover properties, frozen ground data, multiscale observation approach, meteorological variables like wind speed and direction, air temperature, humidity, soil temperature and moisture profiles, snow properties like depth and water equivalent

Definition.Question: What challenges are typically faced in collecting high-quality snow and frozen ground data for alpine hydrological models?
Definition.Answer: The collection of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for alpine hydrological models is challenged by the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography. These conditions inhibit data collection consistency and completeness, which in turn hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and models. Scarcity of observational data due to access difficulties and technological barriers is also a significant issue.

Definition.Question: What does 'gap-free meteorological and hydrological data' mean in the context of environmental observation networks?
Definition.Answer: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data refers to datasets collected from observation networks that are complete and continuous, without missing values, ensuring reliable and comprehensive data coverage. This is achieved through a network of automatic meteorological stations and advanced techniques to capture and monitor processes like snow accumulation, soil freeze-thaw cycles, and other related hydrological variables.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for soil temperature and moisture in the alpine region compare to those for snow cover and frozen ground observations?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection for soil temperature and moisture in the alpine region involves measurements within multiple layers using automatic meteorological stations, whereas snow cover and frozen ground observations utilize snow superstations and frozen ground superstations with advanced instruments like GMON for snow water equivalent and FlowCapt for blowing snow. Soil measurements focus on capturing freeze-thaw processes, while snow and frozen ground observations aim at understanding snow accumulation and ablation processes.

Comparison.Question: How does the integrated observation network in the Heihe River Basin compare to other international networks such as INARCH and CALM in terms of data collection and research objectives?
Comparison.Answer: The integrated observation network in the Heihe River Basin focuses on multiscale hydrometeorological, snow, and frozen ground data for understanding watershed science and functions, similar to international networks like INARCH, which connects observatories for hydrometeorology and snow observation. Unlike CALM, which specifically targets permafrost and climate change, the Heihe network aims at broader hydrological model validation and remote sensing product evaluation in the alpine region.

Interpretation.Question: What considerations might be necessary for ensuring data quality and consistency in an alpine hydrometeorological observation network, given the challenges of high altitude and complex terrain?
Interpretation.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection. These challenges can hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models. Therefore, ensuring data quality and consistency might involve establishing an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network with automatic meteorological stations and superstations, as well as implementing rigorous data processing and quality control measures, such as marking missing data, removing duplicates, and correcting outliers.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of remote sensing data with on-site observations improve the predictive understanding of hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation can improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system and various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data, especially in alpine regions, these need to be validated and calibrated. An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation dataset is essential to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, and evaluate distributed models, ultimately improving the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to integrate observation networks with remote sensing data in alpine hydrology research, and what challenges arise from this integration?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Integrating observation networks with remote sensing data in alpine hydrology research is important to improve the prediction of hydrological processes and address the scarcity of ground-based observations. However, this integration faces challenges due to various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data, especially in the complex terrain of alpine regions, which require validation and calibration to ensure accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons behind the need for next-generation observation networks in alpine regions, and how do these networks aim to address existing research gaps?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Next-generation observation networks are needed in alpine regions due to the scarcity of existing observation data and the significant perturbations to hydrological processes caused by climate change and human activities. These networks aim to provide integrated, distributed, and multiscale datasets, which are essential for accurate hydrological modeling, validation of remote sensing data, and improved understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of integrating remote sensing data with traditional observation networks on the accuracy of hydrological process predictions in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with traditional observation networks can improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing more comprehensive and validated data. However, complexities and uncertainties inherent in remote sensing data, especially in alpine regions, need to be addressed to enhance the predictive understanding of these processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network for alpine hydrology research in the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network is crucial for providing accurate forcing data for alpine hydrological models, validating remote sensing data, and evaluating distributed models. This network aims to advance a predictive understanding of hydrological processes and ecosystem functions in the alpine region, addressing the challenges posed by climate change and human activities.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives are being addressed by collecting long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include investigating watershed science and functions, providing accurate and effective forcing data for hydrological models, integrating observation and simulation data for better understanding, and exploring how climate change and human activities alter fundamental processes. These datasets support the development of alpine hydrological models and improve understanding of hydrological processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals are pursued by monitoring snow and frozen ground properties using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments in the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals are to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, improve the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models, and provide fine-resolution data for validating remote sensing products. This approach is essential for understanding the impacts of snow cover and frozen ground on hydrological processes, especially in regions with complex terrains and climatic conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in establishing and maintaining an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network for alpine hydrology research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in alpine hydrology research involves establishing automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations. The network aims to collect data for validating hydrological models and remote sensing products. At the basin scale, meteorological driving forces are investigated, while at the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations focus on precipitation, soil temperature, and moisture. These data help develop and refine hydrological models. The network includes snow superstations and frozen ground superstations, where remote sensing products are validated using fine-resolution data. Observations include wind, air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, radiation, precipitation, snow depth, snow water equivalent, and more.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can one ensure the quality control and preprocessing of hydrometeorological data collected in challenging alpine conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Quality control and preprocessing of hydrometeorological data in challenging alpine conditions involve several steps: ensuring complete daily data collection with a specified number of data points (e.g., 144 per day), marking missing data with a specific code (e.g., -6999), removing duplicate records, and eliminating data that exceed physical or instrument limits. Any data with potential issues are marked in a distinctive manner (e.g., red text). Date and time formats are standardized, and the data are named systematically (e.g., AWS+site name). These procedures help maintain data integrity and reliability for further analysis.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to capture and measure snow accumulation and ablation processes in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To capture and measure snow accumulation and ablation in alpine regions, state-of-the-art techniques and instruments are used at snow observation superstations. For example, snow depth is measured using ultrasonic sensors like the SR50A, which determine the distance to the snow surface. Snow water equivalent (SWE) is measured using gamma radiation sensors like the CS725 GammaMONitor. Additionally, instruments like FlowCapt are used to measure blowing snow flux at various heights. These methodologies ensure accurate and detailed observations of snow dynamics, crucial for understanding hydrological processes in alpine environments.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the establishment of an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network for alpine hydrology research?
Enablement.Answer: The development and deployment of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations equipped with state-of-the-art techniques and instruments have enabled the collection of gap-free meteorological and hydrological data, snow cover properties, and high-resolution soil physics data. These advancements facilitate the integrated observation network for alpine hydrology research.

Enablement.Question: How do environmental conditions in alpine regions impact the data collection methods for hydrological and meteorological observations?
Enablement.Answer: The cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography present formidable challenges that inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed. These conditions hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models, impacting the overall effectiveness of data collection methods.

Enablement.Question: In what ways can the integration of remote sensing data with ground-based observations enhance the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data with ground-based observations, such as those from automatic meteorological stations and superstations, can improve the prediction of hydrological processes by providing accurate forcing data for hydrological models, validating remote sensing data, and allowing for the evaluation of distributed models. This integration is essential for advancing a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Expectation.Answer: Several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, which hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Expectation.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models, and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using a multiscale observation network in capturing hydrological processes in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of a multiscale observation network is considered effective in capturing hydrological processes as it provides integrated, distributed, and high-resolution data essential for accurate hydrological modeling and remote sensing validation. The challenges of harsh climates and complex terrain are addressed by employing automatic meteorological stations and superstations that capture diverse variables such as snow cover, soil moisture, and freeze-thaw cycles, enabling a comprehensive understanding of alpine hydrology.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, how do existing datasets from observation networks enhance the understanding of ecohydrological processes in alpine regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Existing datasets from observation networks significantly enhance the understanding of ecohydrological processes by offering detailed and long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data. These datasets allow for the investigation of watershed science at multiple scales, improve the accuracy of hydrological models, validate remote sensing data, and help understand the impacts of climate change and human activities on alpine ecosystems, thus providing valuable insights for sustaining downstream ecosystems.

Assertion.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network with automatic meteorological stations and superstations has been established to overcome these challenges, enabling the collection of consistent data even in harsh conditions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used to validate remote sensing data in the context of alpine hydrology and discuss their importance.
Request/Directive.Answer: In alpine hydrology, remote sensing data validation is performed by integrating observations from automatic meteorological stations and superstations for snow and frozen ground. These methods provide high-resolution data to validate remote sensing products, which is crucial for accurately modeling hydrological processes and understanding ecosystem functions affected by snow cover and freeze-thaw cycles.

Request/Directive.Question: Please conduct a search for potential datasets that can provide comprehensive insights into snow cover and frozen ground processes in alpine regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential dataset for studying snow cover and frozen ground processes can be found in alpine observation networks, such as those in the Heihe River Basin. These networks include data from meteorological stations and superstations that capture snow depth, snow water equivalent, and soil temperature and moisture. Such datasets are instrumental for addressing scientific questions related to hydrological modeling and climate change impacts.
